abstract: pmc Cancer Immunol Res Cancer Immunol Res 4147 aacrsd Cancer Immunology Research 2326-6066 2326-6074 pmc-is-collection-domain yes pmc-collection-title AACR Open Access PMC12485383 PMC12485383.1 12485383 12485383 40758122 10.1158/2326-6066.CIR-24-0927 CIR-24-0927 1 Version of Record Immunology Dendritic Cells Tumor Immunology Animal Models Immunotherapy Cancer Vaccines Immunotherapy Metabolism Preclinical Models Animal Models of Cancer Research Articles High Levels of Endogenous Omega-3 Fatty Acids Promote Dendritic Cell Antigen Presentation and Improve Dendritic Cell–Based Cancer Vaccine Efficacy in Mice N-3 Fatty Acids Improve DC-Based Cancer Vaccine Efficacy https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2635-2560 Tiwary Shweta 1 * https://orcid.org/0009-0002-8365-0748 Hsu Kevin S. 1 https://orcid.org/0000-0001-8774-7454 Goldfarbmuren Katherine C. 1 2 https://orcid.org/0009-0000-9664-8546 Xia Zheng 1 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0342-3194 Berzofsky Jay A. 1  1  2 * Corresponding Author: shweta.tiwary@nih.gov Cancer Immunol Res 2025;13:1609–22 01 10 2025 04 8 2025 13 10 498054 1609 1622 20 9 2024 31 1 2025 31 7 2025 01 10 2025 02 10 2025 03 10 2025 ©2025 The Authors; Published by the American Association for Cancer Research 2025 American Association for Cancer Research https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ This open access article is distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivatives 4.0 International (CC BY-NC-ND 4.0) license. DCs from patients with cancer show compromised antigen presentation ability. The authors show that differentiation of DCs in the presence of omega-3 fatty acids enhances their antigen presentation ability and their efficacy as cancer vaccines in mice. Abstract Antigen presentation by dendritic cells (DC) is crucial in activating T cells. DCs capture, process, and present antigens to T cells, making them attractive vaccine vehicles. However, most DC cancer vaccines have had limited clinical efficacy, suggesting a need to increase their potency. We report that high levels of omega-3 fatty acids in mice significantly prolonged lifespan and reduced tumor growth and body weight loss. This effect was mediated in part by more effective DC antigen presentation. WT BMDCs generated in the presence of omega-3 FAs and specialized proresolving lipid mediators (SPM) mimicked the antigen presentation ability of FAT-1 BMDCs in vitro Materials and Methods Reagents The reagents used are as follows: RPMI 1640 (Gibco, 11875-093), FBS (Gibco, A52095-02), glutamine, penicillin/streptomycin (Gibco, 15140-122), beta-mercaptoethanol (Gibco, 21985-023), D-PBS (Gibco, 14190-144), duo ELISA kit IFNγ (R&D Systems, DY485), mouse CD8a T-cell enrichment kit (Miltenyi, 130-104-075), CMFDA cell tracker green dye (Invitrogen, C7025), CMPTX cell tracker red dye (Invitrogen, C34552 Cell lines B16F10 melanoma murine cancer cell line (ATCC, CRL-6475, 2019) was grown in complete RPMI 1640 (cRPMI), comprising RPMI 1640 supplemented with 10% FBS, 100 IU/mL penicillin, 100 μg/mL streptomycin, and 2 mmol/L L-glutamine at 37°C in humidified air with 5% CO 2 2 Mice and vaccination experimental design C57BL/6-Tg(CAG- fat- 1 C. elegans https://www.jax.org/strain/020097 Female mice 10 to 12 weeks old were used for all tumor experiments. For the B16F10 melanoma tumor model, 10 5 5 BMDC generation BM cells were isolated from the femurs of 10- to 12-week-old female FAT-1 or WT mice as previously described ( 18 6 Antigen presentation assay and IFNγ ELISA A total of 20,000 immature BMDCs, either from FAT-1 or WT mice, were plated in 200 μL of cRPMI media in a flat-bottom, 96-well plate. The cells were matured and pulsed with 10 ng/mL LPS and 5 μg/mL hgp100 peptide overnight. The next day, the mature BMDCs were washed with PBS and cocultured with 2 × 10 5 + + 2 DHA ELISA Serum from three FAT-1 and WT animals was obtained, and DHA levels were measured using the BIOMATIK DHA ELISA kit ( EKU08761  Ex vivo Tumor-bearing WT animals vaccinated with either E7-pulsed FAT-1 BMDCs or WT BMDCs were bled (mandibular bleed) 2 to 3 days after the second vaccine dose, and the blood was collected in EDTA tubes. The tubes were centrifuged at 1,500 rpm for 10 minutes, and plasma was collected and frozen at −80°C until further use. Whole blood was plated in U-bottom, 96-well plates and restimulated with E7 peptide (5 μg/mL) overnight and for 48 hours. The cells were washed 3× with PBS, followed by surface staining for immune markers and flow cytometry analysis to detect vaccine specificity and efficacy (see “Flow cytometry”). Cytokine array Plasma was pooled from six independent biological replicates from either WT or FAT-1 tumor-naïve animals, and supernatants from BMDC culture were used to probe the array membrane from the R&D Proteome Profiler Cytokine Array Kit (ARY006). The manufacturer’s protocol was followed, and images were captured using a Bio-Rad imager. The array image was analyzed and quantitated using ImageJ software. T-cell dwell time The antigen presentation assay was set up as described in the “Antigen presentation assay and IFNγ ELISA” section of the “Materials and Methods” section of this article. The DC/T-cell ratio was kept at 1:2, and cells were plated in an eight-chamber glass slide from Ibidi (80841). Live imaging of the coculture was carried out using a Nikon spinning disk confocal microscope overnight. The images were taken 5 minutes apart. Individual T cells were tracked, and the time spent in contact with one or more DCs was calculated per frame per T cell in contact with DCs. Track length generated by individual T cells was calculated using the Imaris software. Flow cytometry Fluorescent protein-labeled antibodies against CD4, CD8, TCRβ, CD45, IFNγ, CD11c, CD11b, MHC class II, CD80, CD86, and CD40 were used (Supplementary Table S1). HPV16 E7 49–57 b L23105 RNA-seq Total RNA from BM cells, immature BMDCs, and mature BMDCs was harvested using an RNA Miniprep Kit from Zymo Research ( R1054 https://github.com/CCBR/RENEE P Data availability The expression profile data generated in this study are publicly available in processed form at https://github.com/NCI-VB/berzofsky_tiwary_FAT1_DCbulk GSE288336 Results High levels of omega-3 FAs extend lifespan and protect against tumor growth in mice To demonstrate the direct impact of elevated omega-3 levels on lifespan extension and cancer protection, we utilized mice with transgene expression of a FAT-1 desaturase gene from Caenorhabditis elegans Fig. 1A 16 17 Fig. 1B Fig. 1C Fig. 1C in vivo Fig. 1D F Fig. 1E Fig. 1G Figure 1. FAT-1 transgenic mice show improved overall survival, lower body mass, and protection against tumor growth compared with WT mice. A, B, C, P D, P E, P F, P G, P H, P I, in vitro J, K, + P L, Statistical analysis: In addition to the improved overall survival of tumor-bearing animals in the FAT-1 group compared with the WT group, we also observed a significant delay in the onset of palpable tumors in the B16F10 melanoma tumor model ( Fig. 1H FAT-1–derived BMDCs are efficient antigen-presenting cells in vitro Although there may be a direct effect of high levels of omega-3 FA on tumor cells in FAT-1 mice ( 19 21 + 22 + 23 24 + Fig. 1J We isolated BM cells from the femurs of FAT-1 and WT mice and generated BMDCs from them to investigate their antigen presentation ability. BMDCs are a good model of the autologous monocyte-derived DCs used in human DC vaccine clinical trials. Mature antigen-pulsed BMDCs were cocultured with CD8 + 25 26 + + Fig. 1K Fig. 1L Our data indicate a greater ability of FAT-1 BMDCs, independent of the DC activation surface molecules, to induce an antigen-specific response by CD8 + FAT-1–derived DC vaccine significantly reduces tumor burden in murine models To evaluate the efficacy of a FAT-1–derived DC vaccine, we vaccinated TC-1 tumor-bearing WT animals with either E7 antigen-pulsed FAT-1 DCs or E7 antigen-pulsed WT DCs, as shown in Fig. 2A Fig. 2B Fig. 2C D Fig. 2E–G 3 Fig. 2H Fig. 2D Fig. 2I Figure 2. FAT-1–derived BMDCs significantly reduce tumor burden in WT TC-1 lung cancer tumor–bearing mice. A, B, C, D, E–G, E F G H, I, P P P We observed similar results in the B16F10 melanoma model. The vaccination timeline was identical to that in the TC-1 lung cancer model; however, in the B16F10 melanoma model, we started the vaccination 5 days after the cells were inoculated due to the aggressive nature of this tumor model ( Fig. 3A Fig. 3C D Fig. 3B 3 Fig. 3G Fig. 3F Fig. 3E Figure 3. FAT-1–derived BMDCs significantly reduce tumor burden in WT B16F10 melanoma tumor–bearing mice. A, B, C, D, E–G, H, 3 3 P P FAT-1–derived DC vaccines induce a better vaccine-specific response ex vivo Our data suggested that the maximum therapeutic benefit of the vaccine was achieved between the second and third doses. Therefore, we decided to test the vaccine-specific T-cell response from different groups at the midpoint of the second and third vaccine doses ( Fig. 4A ex vivo ex vivo + + Fig. 4B + + Fig. 4C + + Fig. 4E + 24 + + + Fig. 4F + + Fig. 4D + + Fig. 4G + + + + + + + Fig. 1H in vivo ex vivo Figure 4. FAT-1–derived BMDCs induce a higher vaccine-specific response ex vivo A, ex vivo B C, + B + + C D, + E–G, + E + + F + + G P P P Bulk RNA-seq analysis reveals DEGs in FAT-1 and WT BM and immature and mature BMDCs As we could not detect any differences in the activation and maturation molecular markers between the FAT-1 and WT mature BMDCs, we performed bulk RNA-seq to evaluate their transcriptomic profiles. We also included BM and immature BMDCs to assess the temporal changes as the cells differentiate from stem cells (BM) to terminally differentiated DCs. FAT-1 BMDCs have higher T-cell dwell time, and supplementation of omega-3 in WT BMDCs mimics FAT-1–like antigen presentation ability in vitro A, B, C, D, E, F, P G, H–K, + P P We hypothesized that with the expression of the genes with potential for regulating migration, synapse formation, and chemokines/cytokines that may serve as attractants for immune cells, it was likely that T cells were spending more time in contact with FAT-1 DCs and, hence, that there would be an increase in T-cell dwell time. To test that hypothesis, we performed live imaging of the coculture of PMEL-1 CD8 + + + Fig. 7D Fig. 7E Fig. 7F Omega-3 FA and SPMs mimic the FAT-1 phenotype in vitro As we observed a significant increase in antigen presentation in coculture experiments with FAT-1 BMDCs and antigen-specific CD8 + Fig. 7G + + Fig. 7H I K Fig. 7J Discussion In this study, we show that a high level of omega-3 FA can improve the antigen presentation ability of BMDCs, thereby enhancing the therapeutic efficacy of DC-based cancer vaccines in murine tumor models. In addition to slower tumor growth, we show an increased ex vivo + Most studies have utilized omega-3 dietary supplementation to investigate its effects on physiology and diseases in rodents and humans ( 29 32 C. elegans 33 34 We found that FAT-1 mice exhibited lower body mass throughout their lifespan and significantly prolonged overall survival compared with WT mice. These findings demonstrate a direct effect of high omega-3 FAs on age-related weight gain and lifespan extension. In line with our observation, recent studies have reported a positive correlation between high omega-3 FAs and decreased mortality risk in humans ( 6 7 We observed that FAT-1 mice demonstrated a decrease in tumor growth rate in various tumor models, including TC-1 lung cancer and B16F10 melanoma, consistent with previous studies ( 19 20 35 de novo 36 39 5 Although we observed no differences in the frequencies of major immune cell subtypes at the basal level, we saw a significant increase in the antigen presentation ability of BMDCs from FAT-1 mice in vitro 40 43 44 45 We have discovered that antigen-pulsed BMDCs from FAT-1 mice can significantly reduce tumor growth and body weight loss and increase overall survival in tumor-bearing WT mice. In addition, we have observed an enhanced vaccine-specific response in both tumor-bearing and tumor-naïve WT mice when vaccinated with antigen-pulsed BMDCs derived from FAT-1 mice. We also observed increased PD-1 + + 46 + + + In this study, we also report the transcriptomic profile of BM cells and immature and mature BMDCs from FAT-1 and WT mice. The bulk RNA-seq from these cell types revealed DEGs that are explicitly upregulated in FAT-1 BM cells and immature and mature BMDCs. Several chemokines and cytokines, such as CXCL2, CCL2, CCL7, CXCL7 Ppbp PF4/CXCL4 47 In addition to these known modulators of immune cells, we also found some upregulated genes in which relevance in DCs is either unknown or poorly understood. HIC1, WWC2, DACH1 CENPF 48 47 49 WWC2 is a protein that acts as a scaffold, regulates the Hippo pathway, and has crucial roles during embryonic development ( 50 51 52 53 Our RNA-seq results have identified factors that can affect the immune synapse between DCs and T cells. To investigate further, we compared the interaction time between FAT-1 and WT BMDCs with T cells. Our data revealed that T cells spent significantly longer (>10-fold) with FAT-1 BMDCs than with WT BMDCs, and the longer dwell time was associated with better T-cell priming and immune response ( 54 One limitation of our study is that most of our data were obtained from a genetic mouse model. However, we observed a similar trend in BMDCs generated in the presence of DHA, at least in vitro In summary, our study demonstrates that high levels of omega-3 have a direct effect on antigen presentation, leading to improved efficacy of cancer vaccines. We propose that this enhanced T-cell response is due to the prolonged interaction between T cells and DCs, increasing T-cell dwell time. Furthermore, this study identifies several molecules with potential roles in enhancing DC function and improving the therapeutic efficacy of DC-based cancer vaccines.
